results.title: Victory in the West = Sieg im Westen
results.brief_description: The official German army film, covering its campaigns in Belgium, Holland and France in May and June of 1940. An army film on the conquest of the Low Countries and France, using authentic material. The campaign is explained in detail with maps. Silent film.

results.title: Victorian vintage
results.brief_description: Dr. W.S. Benwell, a wine specialist, takes the viewer on a conducted tour of the wine growing areas of Victoria. Includes Yeringberg, an old vineyard which has been re-established near Melbourne, Bailey’s vineyard and the Rutherglen Wine Festival, the Swan Hill area, Chateau Tahbilk, the Grampians area of Western Victoria (Great Western Champagne country) and back to Melbourne.

results.title: Victorian Tapestry Workshop
results.creator_credit: Paul Jansen, Ivan Hexter and Victorian Film Corporation
results.brief_description: The Victorian Tapestry Workshop was established in 1976 with State Government assistance. This film shows the efforts of the workshop in transforming a Roger Kemp painting into a major tapestry.

results.title: Victorian cast iron
results.creator_credit: Edward Hayward, BBC-TV and Open University
results.brief_description: A look at some of the remains of Victorian cast iron in Great Britain, and some earlier examples with some discussion as to why they are important and representative of the period. Cast iron has survived better than any of the other new materials discussed, although much was lost for scrap during the wars, and many important monuments are being pulled down yearly.

results.title: Vicki (TEFC)
results.brief_description: A documentary approach to the problems encountered by Vicki, born without arms, and her ways of coping with work, family and her desires for marriage and a family. Produced for television as an introduction to social services available from Government agencies.

results.title: VFL on film 1946-1982: Marking time. - Vol. 2
results.creator_credit: Ken Berryman and National Film and Sound Archive of Australia
results.brief_description: This sequel to VFL on film Vol. 1 is another fascinating compilation of documentary and newsreel footage of the premier Australian Rules Competition between the period from post World War II to the advent of the national competition and includes footage of all twelve League teams. It comprises: 1. The Post-War Powers: Essendon’s golden era; success for the Blues and the Cats. 2. Magpie triumphs. 3. The Demon dynasty: the resurgence of Melbourne in the 1950’s and the one that got away. 4. The New Heroes: the stars of the ‘50’s, ‘60’s and ‘70’s; the Brownlow Medal; victories for the Big V. 5. The Drought Breakers: breakthroughs for the “new” VFL teams and for a foundation member. 6. The Dedicated Fans: rituals in the outer from Victoria Park to Glenferrie Oval. 7. The Television Game: how technology transformed the suburban game. 8. The Big League: the end of the local competition era and its film coverage. Includes rare footage not previously released on video and a detailed commentary by Craig Willis.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ken Berryman and National Film and Sound Archive of Australia

results.title: VFL on film 1909-1945: Marking time. - Vol. 1.
results.creator_credit: Ken Berryman and National Film and Sound Archive of Australia
results.brief_description: To commemorate the Centenary of the Australian Football League, the National Film & Sound Archive produced this outstanding compilation of rarely seen documentary and newsreel footage of the early Victorian Football League (VFL) competition. Highlights include the earliest surviving film of a VFL match - the 1909 Grand Final, Carlton vs South Melbourne, action sequences featuring early legends of the game including Dick Lee, Dave McNamara, Billy Busbridge, Syd and Gordon Coventry, Ivor Warne Smith, Bill Mohr, Alan Hopkins, Jack Titus, Bob Pratt, Jack Dyer, Ron Todd, Jack Regan, Haydn Bunton, and rare footage of supporters. Commentary by Tim Lane. Background notes are contained inside the cover.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ken Berryman and National Film and Sound Archive of Australia
